title: Carnivore Travel Hacks: Avoiding the Airport Food Trap
author: Carnivore Weekly
description: Complete guide to staying carnivore while traveling. TSA-approved packing lists, airport restaurant strategies, flight meal hacks, and international travel tips.
content_html:
You're doing great on carnivore at home. Your fridge is stocked. Your routine is dialed in. Then you book a flight.

And suddenly you're staring at airport food courts wondering if you're about to eat Cinnabon for the first time in six months.

TL;DR

  • Pack TSA-approved foods‚Äîbeef jerky, hard-boiled eggs, cheese sticks, pre-cooked bacon, canned fish
  • Skip the food court‚Äîairport sit-down restaurants have steaks, burgers, and eggs
  • Flight strategy‚Äîeat before boarding, fast during, or request special meals 48 hours ahead
  • International‚Äîmeat is universal, but check customs rules before packing
  • Hotels‚Äîhit the grocery store on arrival for emergency backup meals

Travel is where most people fall off carnivore. Not because they want to quit, but because they didn't plan ahead and got stuck with no options. Here's how the community actually handles it.

The Packing List: TSA-Approved Carnivore Foods

TSA allows solid foods through security. Liquids are the problem. So your carry-on strategy is: pack dry, shelf-stable protein.

ü•©

Beef Jerky

Lightweight, doesn't need refrigeration, high protein. Pack 3-4 bags for a long trip.

ü•ì

Pre-Cooked Bacon

Wrap in paper towels, pack in Ziplock. Smells like bacon on the plane (your seatmate will be jealous).

ü•ö

Hard-Boiled Eggs

Pre-peel at home, pack in a small container. Eat within 24 hours.

üßÄ

Cheese Sticks / Cubes

Can survive a few hours unrefrigerated. Pack in a small cooler bag with ice pack if paranoid.

üêü

Canned Fish

Sardines, mackerel, or salmon. Pack a fork. Don't care what people think.

üçñ

Carnivore Bars

Carnivore Bar, EPIC bars, or Tanka bars. Convenient, expensive, but worth it for travel.

üê∑

Pork Rinds

Crunchy, fatty, keeps forever. Good for snacking between meals.

Pro tip: Bring salt packets. A lot of travel food is under-salted and you'll feel it. Electrolyte packets (like LMNT) are also TSA-friendly and convenient for long flights.

Airport Strategy: Where to Actually Eat

Most airports have at least one sit-down restaurant. That's where you go.

ü•© Steakhouse / Burger
Steak, burger (no bun), eggs, bacon. Easy win every time.
üç≥ Breakfast Spots
Eggs, bacon, sausage. Skip the toast and hash browns.
ü¶ê Seafood
Grilled fish or shrimp. Most airports have at least one option.
üåÆ Mexican
Carnitas or carne asada bowl. No rice, no beans, no tortilla.

Yes, it's overpriced. Yes, the steak won't be amazing. But it's better than breaking your protocol because you got desperate.

Food Court Options (If You're Stuck)

Five Guys Burger, lettuce wrap, extra bacon
Chipotle Carnitas bowl, no rice/beans, extra meat
Shake Shack Burger, no bun, add egg
Any Grill Grilled chicken or beef, skip the rice

Most chains will accommodate "no bun" requests. Don't be shy about it.

The Flight Itself: Your Three Options

Long flights are tricky. You're stuck in a metal tube for 10 hours and the meal service is pasta or pasta.

This is what a lot of carnivores do. Eat a big meal before you board. Don't eat on the plane. Eat when you land.

If you're fat-adapted, fasting for 10-12 hours is easy. You're not going to starve. You'll actually feel better than if you ate the airplane food.

Most airlines let you request special meals 24-48 hours before your flight.

Look for these options:

  • "Low carb meal" ‚Äî usually chicken or fish with vegetables
  • "Gluten-free meal" ‚Äî sometimes has meat and eggs
  • "Diabetic meal" ‚Äî often higher protein, lower carb

It's not perfect, but it's better than the standard pasta tray.

Pack the foods from the packing list above. Eat your beef jerky and hard-boiled eggs mid-flight. Ignore the meal service.

Your seatmate might give you a weird look when you pull out pre-cooked bacon. You're fine.

International Travel: Region by Region

Flying internationally adds complications: longer flights, customs rules, different food cultures.

Customs Rules for Food:

  • Most countries don't allow you to bring meat products across borders. Check before you pack.
  • Commercially packaged foods (jerky, bars) are usually fine. Fresh meat is not.
  • When in doubt, finish your food before you land or toss it before customs.

Good news: Meat is universal. Every culture has steak, chicken, fish, or eggs.

Steakhouses everywhere. Order meat, skip the bread and potatoes. French bistros, German bratwurst, Italian secondi‚Äîmeat is celebrated.

Carnivore paradise. Argentinian asado, Brazilian churrasco. You're literally living your best life here.

Harder but doable. Grilled meats, hot pot (meat only), Korean BBQ, Japanese yakiniku. Avoid sauces with sugar‚Äîthey're everywhere.

Kebabs, grilled chicken, lamb dishes. Easy carnivore wins. Skip the pita and hummus.

The trick is finding sit-down restaurants instead of relying on street food or convenience stores.

Hotel Hacks: Staying Carnivore on the Road

Once you're at your destination, you need a strategy for meals.

üç≥

Hotel Breakfast Buffet

Most hotels have eggs, bacon, sausage. Load up on protein in the morning and you can skip lunch if needed.

üõí

Grocery Store Run

Hit a local grocery store when you arrive. Stock up on emergency backup meals:

  • Pre-cooked rotisserie chicken
  • Deli meat and cheese
  • Hard-boiled eggs
  • Canned fish
üì±

Room Service / Delivery Apps

Most hotels and apps like Uber Eats have steak, burgers, or grilled chicken. Order bunless, skip the sides, add extra protein.

The Mindset Shift

Here's the thing about traveling carnivore: It's not as hard as you think once you accept that your meals won't be perfect.

You're not going to get grassfed ribeye at the airport. That's okay. You're getting protein and fat, staying in ketosis, and avoiding the foods that make you feel like garbage.

Travel is temporary. One suboptimal steak at an airport restaurant won't ruin your progress. But caving and eating pizza because you didn't plan ahead will make you feel worse.

Plan ahead. Pack snacks. Know where the airport restaurants are. And if worst comes to worst, fasting for a few hours won't kill you.

Key Takeaways

  1. Pack TSA-approved foods‚Äîbeef jerky, pre-cooked bacon, hard-boiled eggs, cheese, canned fish, carnivore bars
  2. Airport sit-down restaurants are your friend‚Äîfind the steakhouse or breakfast spot before you fly
  3. Food court chains work‚ÄîFive Guys, Chipotle, Shake Shack all accommodate no-bun requests
  4. Flights: fast, special meal, or BYO‚Äîpick your strategy based on flight length
  5. International: check customs rules‚Äîfinish packaged foods before landing, fresh meat usually isn't allowed
  6. Hotels: grocery store on arrival‚Äîstock up on emergency protein for your room fridge
  7. Accept imperfection‚Äîsuboptimal steak beats breaking protocol

‚ÄîChloe

These are community strategies, not medical or customs advice. Check specific airline and country regulations before traveling. TSA rules may vary.
